Veritasium!
Here's my request for a video to shed light on a subject field seemingly void of attention from public.

Microtransat is a challenge to produce a boat which must autonomously cross the Atlantic.

Has a few caveats, categories, a history and tradition.

E.G: one category wants the boat 2,4 m in length and have no active propulsion.
Yet, all categories mandate, the boat must send some data at a given time interval, stating its position.

So much has happened recently and it is such an interesting field. I feel you would do a fantastic job at exposing all this.

Here's some links for a headstart:
https://www.tu.no/artikler/sailbuoy-ble-forste-autonome-fartoy-over-atlanteren/451678?fbclid=IwAR2TkhvVNK_7bqLhpHRns5ezbbi7Ml5A3sFiOX_K7Y5yRIBeyBc4U0349b0
https://www.microtransat.org/ "the microtransat challenge"

I was part of a team developing a very comprehensive prototype until June this year. A Norwegian party won a category with their sail-buoy: an offshore autonomous drone sensing platform concept.
In many ways, this and many similar challenges are what will deliver the engineers of tomorrow. That's something worth my time right there. Fun, exciting, adventurous, good food for the little grey cells when brainstorming solutions.

There's 3 big failure modes on this this mission:

1) will it be able to land at all and will all instruments be ok and the deployment work right?
2) will the seismometer be on suitably hard ground? (if it's on a shifting substrate it's practically useless)
3) will the depth probe not immediately hit rock?
